I love this app! It keeps me focused and off my phone (in â€œdeep focusâ€œ mode). After a few days, I upgraded to the full subscription, and it's worth it. My favorite feature is that the timer counts up, so I can pause or end a session without losing credit for the focus time I've already put in. This removes the pressure of "all or nothing" timers that penalize you, which can be demotivating.

My only suggestion would be to add some variety to the app's design and soundscapes. For example, the Flora app offers new locations and islands to unlock and explore. I recently switched to FocusTraveller from the Flora app, which I had used for years. It had become virtually unusable because of its glitches. 

I love the intuitive interface of the app, and the graphics are gorgeous. The prompt to take deep breaths are helpful. I love the ability to take breaks and choose your traveler. 

It would be great to see a few valuable features I enjoyed from other productivity apps. 

1. Adding a sense of progression to keep it engaging. In other apps, I liked how spending more time on the app allowed you to unlock new features, like growing new plant species or exploring new areas. It made the experience more rewarding and less monotonous. Introducing a similar gamification element here would be a fantastic addition and help keep users motivated- maybe adding different maps to explore or customization for your traveler (like clothes/accessories or a pet that travels with you). 

1.5: Special badges- the Flora app not only allowed users to unlock new plant species to grow as they spent more time focusing; they also gifted a badge for every plant that was grown either with a friend or through a paid session (putting money on the line). Seeing those badges was very rewarding, so even when I ran out of plants to unlock, I focused on earning both badges for every plant I had. Visual reinforcement for progression is KEY to keeping users interested in coming back to the app. 

2. Allowing users to put money on the line. Flora allowed users to choose a value (between $5-$100) to be charged if they took a break or left the app. This is useful for those who need an extra push to stay focused on their task- it helped me a LOT during finals season.

3. The ability to block distracting apps during the focus session. This adds an extra barrier to simply scrolling on social media while the session is running. I benefitted a LOT from this feature, as I sometimes open distracting apps without even thinking when I get bored. 

4. The ability to add friends without Game Center. I very, very frequently studied with friends through the Flora app. It provides an extra layer of accountability. Providing a QR code or a username to add friends through would be convenient. 

I have diagnosed ADHD, but these features kept me coming back to the Flora app for a little less than four years. I really love FocusTraveller and would love to see the aforementioned updates. I think they would enhance the experience and keep distracted users engaged and coming back for more. 

I hope these suggestions were helpful. Thanks for reading my review!

I struggle a lot with focusing and motivation for basically everything (probably ADHD lol), and all the other apps Iâ€™ve tried like this were kind of meh at best and i only was consistent at studying for a couple days at best. As for some of the content itself, it doesnâ€™t hold your hand with romaji (or rather, itâ€™s a setting I turned off to make it harder on myself and more effective), it cleverly gives you simple yet common words to help learn the kanas, thereâ€™s actual audio from an actual person, and thereâ€™s clever spaced repetition! è©•è«–.æ¨™é¡Œ: Takes it to a higher level
è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: Had a 3,000+ streak on Duolingo, just finished a year subscription with Babbel. Lingvist is much better than both. Quickly builds your vocabulary while giving you engaging ways to deploy it.

è©•è«–.æ¨™é¡Œ: Best flash card language learning app!
è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: I have been learning with Lingvist for a year now. I feel like I have actually learned and retained quite a bit of information. The spaced repetition algorithm in this app is like magic. Also learning the most frequently spoken words is way more useful than learning random nouns and verbs that youâ€™ll probably never use, which seems to be common in other apps. I was hesitant to spend the money but Iâ€™m committed to learning foreign languages (Russian,Spanish,mandarin), and I can say it was worth it. I upgraded to the 10 year subscription when they had a promotion. Hopefully they add Mandarin Chinese in the future. If you really want to learn a foreign language, this app really works!

Overall, I like the flash card style of this app and itâ€™s focus on vocab in context, however itâ€™s missing some things I would consider core features. 

There is no was to view conjugations for a word within the app, making it difficult to associate verbs with their other forms. 

There is no option to mark a mistake as a typo for a word you DID know, so you must waste time with many repetitions of known words. In the reverse, if you forgot a known word and want to change itâ€™s status back to new or learning, this is not possible. 

Itâ€™s support for synonyms seems almost nonexistent. There are many words that can correctly be answered several ways, but it will only accept one answer, and all you can do is remember for that specific prompt, which synonym is correct.

I donâ€™t like the app. I want to change the voice. I also donâ€™t like how the words shuffle. Itâ€™s a lot of mÃ©morisation rather than learning. The app also tricked me into buying, I pressed trial and it charged for the whole year and then I couldnâ€™t get a refund.

è©•è«–.æ¨™é¡Œ: Very useful with just a few issues
è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: Great way to get 15 minutes of targeted vocab learning every day. My issues with it are that 1) it doesnâ€™t support multi-word expressions, which are pretty important, 2) the words arenâ€™t connected to a complete dictionary so you have to leave the app to get a full definition, 3) itâ€™s the same womanâ€™s voice and you get sick of it, also itâ€™s used for masculine words (like sheâ€™d say â€œestoy cansadoâ€, which is confusingâ€”speaking of which, sometimes it gives you no clue whether to use o or a), and 4) it doesnâ€™t distinguish between rare and frequent words, so you learn a lot of rare ones. All that being said, the algorithm is well-designed, so it does work!

Overall I like this app but it has flaws. The app should accept alternative words in the phrases, not insist on me having to learn another word. I already know how to say this. (learning a language is hard enough) Secondly, the voice option capitalizes the first spoken word (when more than one word is needed) and then it doesnâ€™t accept the solution, it wants lower case , then I end up having to type it in by hand. Sort of negates the voice option. Thirdly: Everything is spoken by a robot who really canâ€™t pronounce Italian 100%. It sounds like an alien and according to my Italian teacher the robot actually makes mistakes inflecting some words the wrong way. Recordings of real people would be much better. Also the algorithms throw the words at you that you donâ€™t know, especially within the first 10-20, out of 50.  It would be better to intersperse it more; ask for words we already know, so we can first warm up a little and feel better about ourselves. Whatâ€™s good: learning words in context, in sentences. It doesnâ€™t look like a stupid videogame. I donâ€™t want virtual trophies and be overly praised for no reason. 

In case any of you Schmucks are actually ever reading this: we should not be rated by including the new word performance! After all, theyâ€™re new! Percentages should be based on repeats only. 
Bye. Off to find something better.

I clicked on the 14 day free trial thing and started using the app. Within a few minutes a charge for a full year membership showed up on my banking. Donâ€™t sign up for the free trial! It doesnâ€™t work!

This app is good at drilling vocab, until itâ€™s not. Iâ€™m learning Spanish and find it really annoying that there are no explanations. Iâ€™m constantly just guessing on what word or ending they want. I can force these words into my brain but Iâ€™m not actually learning. The WHY is pretty much missing from this app. There are some short grammar explanations separate from the vocab but even those are very thin. I wish I hadnâ€™t purchased a subscription.
I like the user experience of this app as much or more than Duolingo. However, there wasnâ€™t an easy way to continue learning after the free trial ran out so I deleted it.
there is confusing words function on android, but I canâ€™t see it on iOS

è©•è«–.æ¨™é¡Œ: Lingvist is like a MAGIC WAND for language acquisition
è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: Lingvist is hands down the best language learning app out there, and, believe me, I have tried them all (including all of the fully paid versions). I took French in school, but never learned to actually speak the language (despite always getting As). Over the years, I have wanted to fix that and finally learn the language for real, once and for all. I am not exaggerating when I say I have tried ALL the language learning apps out there (and not just the free versions, but the fully paid subscriptions). Many were useless, some were very good, but nothing compares to Lingvist. When I started using Lingvist, MAGIC happened. Suddenly, I was able to read novels (actual novels written for adults) in French, including books that I had purchased years ago but given up on as impossibly difficult, and even watch many movies/TV shows in French (something I had all but forsaken). Lingvist made my vocabulary EXPLODEâ€”and somehow, I just remember the words I learn in Lingvist so much better than through other similar apps. As if that werenâ€™t enough, Lingvist has an amazing feature that lets you create custom decks of words to learn. All you have to do is type in a list of words you want to learn, and Lingvist defines them and creates sentences with them. You can even tell Lingvist to expand on your custom list and find other similar words to add. I have no idea why Lingvist is so much more effective than other similar apps, but it just is. Itâ€™s like a magic wand for language acquisition. I feel like I have had pixie dust sprinkled on me.

This is it. Mix this with Pimsleur and Babbel with some real conversations from HelloTalk and you will be fluent. This app is by FAR the best vocab and grammar app there is and for only $10 a month ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

This scientifically honourable app is a very efficient way to learn lots of vocabulary, plus a bit of grammar, for a reasonable price. It's the only language app I've found that isn't based on marketing and extremely sectionalised repetition of some random content. Unfortunately, I must currently leave one star off since most of the courses contain several flashcards with grammatical errors or insufficient explanation, plus that a minority of the courses seem to have many flashcards out of place, plus the glitch I encountered when subscribing. This app is still generally very good for language learning, especially if learners also use media for stuff like grammar or practise, and I'd like to see it improve and expand in the future.

Honestly this way of learning is not entertaining but itâ€™s very efficient. If you commit to 50 cards/day (I did 60) then you can learn very quickly. Iâ€™m a native French speaker and I went to Italy after 6 months with the app and I was able to get by in most situations and people impressed by how quick the app was able to make me progress (+) very efficient if youâ€™re commited (-) hard to commit

The interface is uninteresting. Vocabulary review uses confusing examples. No interactive dialog options, no way to see progression. Sad I paid for. I assumed there would be more than in the free version. Will not be renewing.

This has an expansive vocab set, more than most apps Iâ€™ve seen. Howeverâ€¦

The fill in the blank style questions have varying degrees of quality for the prompt. Iâ€™m studying Spanish which has formal and familiar verb and pronoun forms. Often, thereâ€™s no indication of which to use; youâ€™ll be marked wrong and will suffer through having to repeat this question. You can mute particular questions, which works around this, but it shows that attention to detail isnâ€™t there. Other times, the hints are wildly inaccurate or use an obscure minor definition of the word, rather than the more common definition.

All in all, I donâ€™t feel like youâ€™re getting quality thatâ€™s superior to Duolingo and the price is much higher.

I love using this app to increase my German vocabulary! The UI is very pleasant and easy to use, and there are so many subject decks itâ€™ll probably keep me busy for years!

Had an old account and wanted to retake the placement test. This was not an option so I made a new account to take it. Then tried to subscribe. Great tool for vocab but one thing that would make it great is if they had images to go along with the words for diff. objects.

I didnâ€™t like this app and pretty much immediately deleted it. It is not fun at all. I so rarely care enough about an app to write a review, but this is the app Iâ€™ve been dreaming of. A functioning placement test, new words, and actual progression unlike most language apps that force you to fixate on the same phrases like â€œI eat the appleâ€ for three weeks. Iâ€™m only a few days into the free trial and already my vocabulary has expanded drastically. Totally worth the money. Amazing app.

I signed up for the monthly plan. The app didnâ€™t register my payment even though I had clearly paid.

I didnâ€™t cancel my Apple subscription. It worked for 1 extra cycle. I thought all was well and that they decided to stop their shenanigans.

My subscription just renewed today, and guess what? The app tells me my free trial is over and locked me out. Yes, let me make that clear â€”

I had a free trial. I donâ€™t remember how long it was or how I got it to be honest because it lasted a while. I like learning multiple different languages. I saw some people talking about how Lingvist is Duolingo for adults. I donâ€™t even understand the comparison because they teach in two completely different ways. Iâ€™ve done my fair share of apps to learn languages and I donâ€™t know if any really help in the way they think they do? Clearly itâ€™s just my opinion in how it helps me. 

I used it to practice Norwegian and Korean. Focusing solely on my experience with this app, I donâ€™t know if I can say either really helped me with grammar? Both of the languages have nuances in a sense where very similar vocabulary is used but it may be spelled differently or itâ€™s dependent upon the tone of formality used. I will say, I was happy to see that in the Korean lessons, they noted the formality to be used. On the other hand, with both languages, there was no context or formal introduction to the words? I used to like Memrise for this specific reason. You would learn vocabulary and gradually work up to it being used in a sentence. It used to give you the chance to understand context. 

Lingvist just feels like a list of vocabulary words set in front of you that you have to memorize and it leaves it at that. There arenâ€™t really quizzes or anything to test rapid recall or some way to really gauge it? Itâ€™s just either you remember or you donâ€™t. It doesnâ€™t feel all that engaging to me is I guess the way I would sum it up. Iâ€™m thankful for the free trial I had because it seems you canâ€™t use a single thing in the app without some form of subscription or free trial active so thereâ€™s that. Iâ€™m glad there are people getting so much out of it but it just doesnâ€™t seem to have benefited me all that much.

After one day the app makes you provide payment info. NOT happening. Iâ€™m very much happy to consider a subscription or one-time payment, b/c of course. But donâ€™t put the onus on your potential client or customer to *remember to reach out* if they donâ€™t want to continue. This understandably makes a lot of us avoid you

Makes your brain hurt but Iâ€™ve definitely have been able to learn and understand German way better than some other apps I tried. Not only that but it gives you context when and why the word is used. Setting your goals and also reminding you is a great feature for this app.

Those complaining this is an expensive purchase are most likely the same people who blow $10 at Starbucks every morning for a .50 cent drink you could make at home. I have already expanded my German vocabulary by hundreds of words in less than a week, and it's so much more fluid to delve into than Duo or Rosetta. Love the design and functionality of the app. There is always obviously room for improvement. Excited to see new ideas and iterations.

è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: Wow. I paid for a year and canceled the service after that. Then I emailed the company to see if they had a lifetime purchase option. The app detected the wrong language right off the bat. I canâ€™t read the app because of this. I think I changed it to English but it doesnâ€™t change the way the app displays to me. So of course I canâ€™t do anything. Please delete it.

As with every language learning app or method, I wouldnâ€™t rely on it solely without other supplements, but the spaced repetition system that it uses is extremely effective at teaching new vocabulary. As far as learning sentence structures, pronunciation, actual dialogue, and so forth, Iâ€™d recommend Pimsleur or Rosetta Stone. This is certainly worth the subscription fee though - Iâ€™ve been using it for years now with great success.

I think a great improvement to this app would be the ability to learn short phrases. Learning one word as a time is great, but as I get more advanced I find it more helpful to remember the 2-3 word phases that are most important and common in a sentence. It also prevents learners from trying to translate word by word. No other app does this well, and would love to see this continue to be the best app. Easily my most used app for learning Spanish.

This is the best app for building vocabulary. It is extremely well designed. I review/learn 50 French words a day. (You can set your own goal.) The app makes me recall the words correctly 5 times, then a few days later tests me on the learned words. If I forgot them, I get to review them again for five times. The developers obviously know how humans learn - with repetition and over a long period of time. I have tried other language learning apps but this one is the best because it was made based on how human learn - with repetition and coming back to what you have learned to make sure you have actually retained the knowledge.  

After using the app for many months, I am noticing some annoying bugs. The custom deck feature does not work. And after finishing the Â« general deck Â» the app is having trouble giving me new words to practice. These are very annoying bugs that should be corrected soon.

In ways, Lingvist is Duolingo for grownupsâ€”more advanced and without Duolingoâ€™s annoying animations and autogenerated encouragement. And Lingvist does a much better job of targeting the areas where a particular user needs work. But Lingvist has a key shortcoming: it doesnâ€™t help users understand why a particular synonym is correct in a particular context. Why, for instance, is â€œgleichâ€ rather than â€œnunâ€ or â€œjetztâ€ the right answer for a particular prompt? Occasionally a notification tells the user that the answer isnâ€™t wrong but isnâ€™t the word Lingvist is trying to teach, but even these notifications often donâ€™t appear when they should. And the English translations seem unreliable. For instance, â€œErmÃ¶glichenâ€ and â€œsorgen fÃ¼râ€ are both translated as â€œensureâ€, but â€œmake possibleâ€ and â€œtake care toâ€ are probably better translations. And obviously â€œyieldâ€ isnâ€™t the right translation for the past-tense verb â€œergabâ€.  Consequently the user too often must simply learn by rote to provide a particular answer for a particular prompt without knowing why.

I donâ€™t usually write reviews for apps but this one hits home. An excellent app for habit tracking along with many cool little features. I can tell that the team took their time when making this app. Looking forward to have more features coming out and get more credits for what its worth.

This is my favorite habit tracking app so far! The interface is very flexible and easy to understand. There are tons of icons to match your habits and they are all super cute. The life-long subscription fee is very cheap compared to others. This app not only has functions you can get for ordinary habit-building apps, but they also include other functions usually unavailable on other apps, such as big-days-countdown, setting long-term goals, and collecting achievement cards. There is tomato timer function too, so you can track the time you spend on every habit. The developers really care about user feedbacks and they even build an social media group to collect these feedbacks.

Learning a language with Ule is based on spaced repetition method â€” a scientifically proven way to enrich vocabulary. We determine your current level of English and provide you with a tailored learning program. Each day you will learn 8 words, it's about 250 words per month or 3000 words per year. 

To keep you in a good language shape we'll ask you to repeat learned words and expressions. The app contains 5 learning mechanics for better memorizing. You can choose specific topics of your interest among 29 areas.

Ule contains the following subscription options:
â€” Weekly with 3 days free trial at $9.99; Yearly with 3 days free trial at $99.99;
â€” Subscription automatically renews unless auto-renew is turned off at least 24-hours before the end of the current period. Account will be charged at the full price of the chosen subscription period. Account will be charged for renewal within 24-hours prior to the end of the current period
â€” Payment will be charged to iTunes Account at confirmation of purchase.
â€” Any unused portion of a free trial period, if offered, will be forfeited when the user purchases a subscription to that publication.
â€” Subscriptions may be managed by the user and auto-renewal may be turned off by going to the userâ€™s Account Settings after purchase.

Learn to read sheet music and improve your sight-reading skills with Music Tutor. Develop your speed and accuracy in reading sheet music by identifying music notes in timed sessions. Choose to practice with notes in treble, bass and alto clefs in timed or untimed sessions. After each test, you can review your mistakes and see your progress.

Other features of Music Tutor include:

â€¢ Custom Practice Range - Set your own range of notes that you want to practice with.
â€¢ Supports notes up to 4 ledger lines above or below the staff on any of the clefs.
â€¢ Notes Reference Charts - For Treble, Bass and Alto clefs.
â€¢ MIDI Support - Connect your keyboard or digital piano using Lightning to USB Camera Adapter and respond directly from your instrument.
â€¢ Companion Apple Watch app using which you can practice recognising music notes on the go.

æ‡‰ç”¨åç¨±: Listening for the TOEIC Â® Test
æ‡‰ç”¨æè¿°:
It's not easy to get a high score on TOEIC Listening test if you have not practiced your listening skills. "Practice makes perfect". You have no choice to practice your TOEIC listening skill before taking your actual test with a high score.
Here we provide you a great tool that you can use to practice your TOEIC listening skill at anytime, anywhere on your mobile phone.

This app is to provide you a huge number of practices with full of listening skills like Picture Description, Questions & Responses, Short Conversations and Short Talks. We believe that you can get your highest  score on TOEIC listening actual test after practicing all of our practices.

Not just the TOEIC testing material, we are also working hard to make this app easy to use, so you will feel the most comfortable when using this app.

KEY FEATURES:
+ Huge collection of TOEIC test
+ Support All TOEIC listening skills
+ View Answer Keys and Transcripts
+ Playback Transcripts
+ Record your testing results
+ Share to friends

Let try this app a try and let us know what you think and how you feel.

è©•è«–.å…§å®¹: Only three of the four multiple choice answers show up on my screen, must not be suitable for smaller phone screens. I have an iPhone SE.
Good study tool for vocab but when using the quiz now, the forth option is cut off from selecting. Maybe itâ€™s only for phones with larger screens? (Have an iPhone SE)

Good practice but the pronunciation voice sound is not something you want to replicate or even pay attention to. The reverse mode is by far the best for studying.  Wish there was a way to group words more easily than favorites.

I just love this little app. You get a lot of words for free, plus there are three modes. It doesn't have SRS or anything too fancy but your word familiarity is ranked by 0 to 3 stars so you get to "level up" your words.
It's Need to have easier way to learn kanji..

This app is great when it comes to learning new words in Japanese, as well as a variety of useful kanji. However, it does not go in to depth on how those words are, or can be, conjugated when used in sentences.
Pretty useful but room for improvement. Multiple choice makes it easy to think you know vocabulary just by eliminating the wrong answers. Would be nice if could quiz only on words marked as favorite.

If you just want to expand your vocabulary then this is a good app however I wished there were themed grouping of testing, like one section would be food, the other be greetings, something like that. However the app does not provide much help in anything else. But I guess if you end up learning all the words you'll have a rough understanding of what a Japanese person is saying.

This is an app okay if you want to study all 700 words in the beginners level at once. That is impossible at discouraging. We need to be able to work on a smaller group of words repeatedly. Say like 10-20 words specific words. Not 10/20 of 700. Once the app implements that I will give it a 5 star.
The limited free Japanese pronunciation voice does not work.

I use this app to review JLPT vocab I already know and to easily learn and review words I don't know. The interface is simple and easy to use. The audio doesn't sound robotic, which came be very distracting for me.
This app gets you going. I am motivated to learn because I want to pass ever level!ğŸ˜€

I'm an advanced student of Japanese. This app is very helpful to me. You won't find any other apps that so well combine native audio pronunciation with the corresponding kanji/kana. If you own an iPhone and are learning Japanese, get this app now.
This app is good for vocabulary and pronunciation, but you are required to know the basic alphabet to fully utilize it

Simplistic and cheap quite useful though instead of simple push notifications maybe add support for kanji of the day with an ability to set frequency. Along with options to see familiar or unfamiliar words and so forth would make this app shine.
This has been a great app for reviewing vocabulary words. I like how the app has been formatted.

This is a great app if you want quick vocab training on the go. It only has level N5 by default, but you can unlock all other levels for just $5, which is pretty good. The quiz layout is simple and easy to drill yourself with. There is one issue that keeps me from giving it five stars, however. It's that your mastery of words is not recorded separately for the three quiz types. For example, say I take the default quiz (japanese word with english multiple choice options) a few times and master a word in that quiz. That word is now also mastered in the kanji quizzes and the reversed vocab quiz (the one that gives an english word with japanese multiple choice options). Even if i have never studied that word reversed or studied its kanji, it will not appear in the other quiz types. I think it would be much more helpful if all three quiz sections were completely separate from each other, and i was forced to master every word in every category. Despite this, the app is still worth trying out and purchasing if you like it.
I find it to be an enjoyable way of practicing vocabulary. It's somewhat easier than say the anki core 2k. I find it useful for exposure, and quickly rewarding.
I searched forever for a good Japanese-learning app, and this is by far my favorite! I'd definitely recommend it to anyone wanting to expand or brush up on their Japanese vocab.
Great tool for learning lots of Japanese words. Would love to see this app developed for other languages! (Korean, Chinese, etc.)
I enjoy the three different quizzes, the example sentences for each word, and the achievement challenges.

This is a really good app, but you miss the sound of kanjis.
for example è¦‹ have two ways to read, one is ã¿ãˆã‚‹ another is ã‘ã‚“ã€‚
Your app doesn't have later one. please check my opionion plz. If you consider my review, this app would be greater than now!
Great vocab and good way of becoming familiar
Best Japanese vocab app out there. Great for all levels of learning.
The expansion price is cheap, the quiz being adjustable by tens is helpful, automatically playing the spoken version is helpful, and the starting with over 650 (JLPT5) vocabulary words is very nice.
Although it's not perfect, I feel this is a great tool for learning Japanese vocabulary.
My friend in Japanese school told me about this app. Great way to improve my vocabulary!
Great vocabulary quiz--I see repeated words often enough to learn them, but also regularly get new words, too. Excellent for a fairly new beginner like me.
The only thing, is that some of the pronunciation is wrong and some of the kana is misspelled.

There are other great Japanese vocab learning apps but this is the only one I've found with an amazing interface, and it has native speakers speaking each word. It's so hard to find info on pitch in Japanese, and with this you won't have to worry. Just practice each word as you hear it, and it has all you need for any level of jlpt. Well worth it, better than Japanese flip even :-)

This app is a lot of fun and has been very helpful. I enjoy unlocking achievements while learning new words and how to recognize kanji!!! It's terrific!!! I would love even more words this is the best app!!
It's a good app. I practice the vocabulary quiz once in a while, I always learn something new. Good work.
Nice big selection of vocabulary. Simple but fun!

Just what I wanted: premade flashcards with English to Japanese, Japanese to English, and (rare find!) kanji to hiragana. It's straightforward to use and won't bog you down with a million useless example sentences like other apps, which read more like textbooks than like time-killers. A great way to practice and review. 5 stars.

I love this app! I get to learn many, many words. The only thing I don't like, it's the not knowing when you reach the next star in your learned word process. I know lesson N5 like the back of my hand in all three modes and I have yet to reach more than one star in any word. I'm beginning to think that you never advance. It's a bit frustrating but doesn't take away from the learning experience.

I love this app it is really fun doing the quizzes and challenging yourself to learn the new words you don't know. Of course this app is better once you have already studied Genki 1 and Genki 2 because the first level n5 quizzes you on most of the words learned in Genki 1 .
Easy to use, intuitive and full-featured; this app is great for basic vocabulary exercises.

Use it as a way to quiz yourself, look things up on the spot like a dictionary, or maybe learn how to spell things by typing the definition? This app is a super easy way to learn Japanese vocabulary as well as practice your reading skills in Japanese.

It is really a good app to learn Japanese. Also you quiz your self in 3 different ways using the app. The audio is a big help. I don't know why it has few review.
It is really good. Just try it.

This is no good. I'm a complete newbie at Japanese, but even I can spot this application is riddled with errors, example sentences aren't quite right, mixed up words (such as mixing up green and blue) etc. The premise of the app is good, but the editing is awful. They have a 'report error' button, but needing your audience to correct you sort of defeats the purpose of a vocabulary study guide. I worry, how many wrong things am I accidentally being taught from this app? I really hope you guys get a better editor, it could be a really great app.
It's great for building vocabulary and kanji recognition. It would be nice if SRS (spaced repetition system) was added in the future.
Recent updates to this app have made a good study tool into a fantastic one! Native audio is a plus, too!
It is a great way to learn and remember with a quizz.

This is an awesome app. I like that it has achievements and keeps track of my correct answers. Many apps are just lists if vocabulary. Some of the questions are too easy though, like only one answer ends in ru so obviously it's the right answer. Fix this and it will be even better!
The new update is not staying open.  Please fix.

I have learned Japanese for a while but never familiarized myself with enough vocabs. I have to say this is hands down the best app for Japanese vocab. I highly recommend it and the cost is nothing compared to the invaluable learning this app can provide.
I believe having quizzes are the best way to learn! I really liked how there are more than one modes of quizzing. Great job!
